Brew Guide

Great coffee deserves great brewing. Master the fundamentals and elevate your daily ritual.

The Fundamentals

Fresh Coffee

Use coffee within 2-4 weeks of roasting for optimal flavor. Store in an airtight container away from light and heat.

Grind Fresh

Always grind just before brewing. Pre-ground coffee loses flavor rapidly. Adjust grind size based on your brew method.

Water Quality

Use filtered water heated to 195-205¬∞F (90-96¬∞C). Water quality directly impacts your coffee's taste.

The Golden Ratio

1:16

Coffee to Water Ratio

For every 1 gram of coffee, use 16 grams (ml) of water.
Example: 20g coffee ‚Üí 320ml water

This is a starting point. Adjust to taste: use more coffee for stronger brew, less for lighter.

Pour Over Method

1 Heat Water

Bring filtered water to 200¬∞F (93¬∞C). Let boiling water rest for 30 seconds.

2 Prepare Filter

Place filter in dripper and rinse with hot water. This removes paper taste and preheats your vessel.

3 Grind Coffee

Grind 20g of coffee to medium-fine consistency (like sea salt). Add to filter and create a flat bed.

4 Bloom

Pour 40ml of water in a circular motion to saturate grounds. Wait 30-45 seconds for bloom.

5 Pour

Slowly pour remaining water (280ml total) in concentric circles. Maintain steady flow. Total brew time: 2:30-3:00.

6 Enjoy

Remove dripper, swirl gently, and enjoy immediately. Notice the clarity and complexity of flavors.

Pro Tips

Grind Size Matters

Espresso: Fine (like table salt)
Pour Over: Medium-fine (like sea salt)
French Press: Coarse (like breadcrumbs)

Troubleshooting

Too bitter? Lower water temp or use less coffee
Too sour? Increase water temp or grind finer
Weak flavor? Use more coffee or grind finer

Storage Tips

Keep beans in an airtight container in a cool, dark place. Never refrigerate or freeze. Buy in quantities you'll use within 2-3 weeks.

Experiment

These are guidelines, not rules. Adjust ratios, temperatures, and times to find your perfect cup. Keep notes on what works.
